question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The discussion groups were great for facilitation discussion in ways that lectures don't allow. I found community in met group, entirely with people of different faiths and experiences. 
The diversity of the instructors was great, both in their fields but also in their ways of conducting the class. 
Best of all, the discussions between the instructors was fantastic. I loved hearing the students questions and listening to how the instructors found agreement and disagreements within their faiths, and how they dealt with challenging questions that arose. This was an opportunity I think people rarely get.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

knowledge: learned about the history of the Israel/Palestine conflict, the different actors involved in the region over time, how to think about the issue from different perspectives, and how to think about new frameworks toward peace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading and skimming through a lot of content in a short amount of time, knowledge gathering skills, critical thinking and analysis of texts. Exam preparation skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, we learned to examine history through a personal lens by analyzing memoirs and primary sources from varying perspectives. We also learned to engage in texts by completing weekly reading responses. Lastly, we learned to pull out thematic patterns and common threads over the course of Israeli-Palestinian history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course gave me so much more context to understand the situation in Israel-Palestine and helped me to develop the skills to approach understanding longstanding conflict. Learning to think about how to make compromises between groups with so much animosity was incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach the Israeli-Palestinian conflict with numerous perspectives. I learned how to write critically and analyze readings. I also learned the deep history of the conflict which I didn't know existed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I left the class with my analytical writing skills much better than they were previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would definitely continue using films, clips, and media to teach.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should absolutely sign up for this course.  Dr. Weinthal and Dr. Stein are tremendous teachers who help break down the complexity of the Israel/Palestine conflict without ever minimizing the difficulties of it.  The class will teach you so much about human rights, natural resources, state-building, and the history of one of the most visible global conflicts.  You won't just learn about what happened, you will be asked to engage directly with thehuman dimensions of this conflict and confront the difficult realities of the past and current situation.  This class is a must take.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the post-war discussion and knowledge surrounding the Holocaust and WWII in Germany. It was something that I had never learned about; I always learned about the Holocaust, but never the intellectual aftermath. I also learned some film methods and techniques, since this class was an ALP and we watched a decent amount of movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a range of knowledge, skills, and insights that have significantly enriched my understanding of the subject matter. One specific thing I learned was the importance of critical thinking and analysis. Through various assignments and class discussions, I honed my ability to evaluate arguments, assess evidence, and identify logical fallacies, enabling me to approach complex issues with a more discerning eye. Additionally, I gained a deeper appreciation for the power of effective communication. Whether it was through written assignments and class discussions, I learned how to articulate my ideas clearly and persuasively, tailoring my message to different audiences and contexts. Lastly, this course exposed me to diverse perspectives and challenged my preconceived notions. By engaging with classmates from various backgrounds and exploring different viewpoints, I developed a greater sense of empathy and cultural awareness, fostering a more inclusive and open-minded way of thinking. Overall, these three specific learnings—critical thinking, effective communication, and embracing diversity—have not only enhanced my academic abilities but also equipped me with invaluable skills for navigating the complexities of the world beyond the classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: All about WWII and post germany

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the depths of how Germany and German people responded to the Holocaust and, as the course is titled, came to terms with their past. I was able to develop a greater perspective on the Holocaust and a better understanding of everything that went into the persecution of Jews and others during the Holocaust.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: reading academic/historical texts, approaching difficult topics with nuance

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about the Holocaust and German reconciliation with its past, ways to consider multiple perspectives on historical events, how German understanding of the Holocaust changed in the decades after the Holocaust.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I improved my German vocabulary and speaking skills. I learned about so many new German authors and works and how to analyze and discuss complicated pieces of writing. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I continued the development of my language proficiency. Throughout the semester, I received many opportunities to practice my German through different activities targeting writing, reading, listening, and speaking. By the end of the course, I felt particularly proud of my improved reading skills. I found the texts to be quite challenging, but ultimately led to immense improvements in my German reading comprehension. I also developed a greater understanding of Jewish-German history and culture in the Modernist time period. I had already consumed some of the media (film and literature mainly) that we discussed in this course, but through our in-depth class discussions, I learned to see these and many new materials through alternative perspectives. It was particularly exciting to discuss the context of different works and ponder the potential implications these contexts could have on the overall meaning of literature, film, and art. Finally, this course helped me develop an understanding of and an appreciation for the interconnectedness of people and ideas. Throughout the course, we saw the connections and overlap between the authors, artists, filmmakers, and philosophers located in Berlin, Prague, and Vienna. It truly made me appreciate and ponder the ways in which information is spread. And, how inspiration is spread as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I practiced my German language skills, learned more about Jewish history and culture in central Europe, and gained skills in critically analyzing texts and films in German.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in an in-depth, comprehensive look at a moment in German history and culture. Through a journey of popular and more obscure works of art, literature, and cinema, you will develop an understanding of the major anxieties, joys, and dilemmas present within the thoughts, livelihoods, and innovations of the early 1900s German-Jewish culture.

response_text: I very much liked the homework design and thought it accompanied the class well, including the Cafe Ivrit conversation hours that were held to encourage outside-of-class interaction with Hebrew. One of the other major components of the course was the portfolio, which was helpful but also a bit ambiguous in its purpose. As a place to summarize out-of-class Hebrew experiences (this was my interpretation), I found this helpful, but then I don't understand the point of spending valuable time on formatting rather than the content. I was also seeing different interpretations throughout the class. If this is truly meant to be a "choose your own adventure" style of project, I would recommend grading it as such—if people don't think formatting is going to be intellectually stimulating, look to the components they list. If there was a more material realization to the project, I would recommend providing some examples so people can focus their effort on the intellectually-stimulating task at hand.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think my biggest wish was that had done more that applied to current times and modern Hebrew versus all the grammar and structure of sentences, for example. I know that grammar is obviously an important part of the language, but I think it is also important to learn about things beyond the rules. For example, it would have been cool to have a class on Israeli slang, and see what words and phrases are actually very common in Israel. I also wish we had done a bit more with pop culture. We had a poet come in to speak to us and we read his work, and I really enjoyed that, so I think doing more of that or watching an episode of an Israeli TV show or listening to Israeli songs and talking about them could be very beneficial. Basically, I just think we should have done more that exposed us to real Israeli culture (that would also help with our understanding of the language) than we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I took Hebrew for all of my growing up life, and was really excited to improve my speaking skills by taking it at Duke. Whatever I was expecting, though, was not what I was met with. Prof. Baker is very kind, enthusiastic, and fair in her assignments and her grading; that said, we spent the entire semester reviewing grammar forms that I learned in middle school and early high school.While this was a nice review, I can confidently say that I did not learn speak and write any more fluently, did not pick up any slang or the ability to watch fast-paced Hebrew movies, and did not read real Hebrew literature. We worked out of a workbook the entire semester, only read news articles on a platform with small articles meant for Hebrew beginners, and even when we expressed the desire to learn from more applicable sources were not met with engaging, challenging material. Classes were essentially a lecture, with hardly any Hebrew spoken by us. This would have been a good intermediate class, but was definitely not meant to be a 300-level language course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how the World Wars shaped the development of states in the Middle East
2) I learned, through Dr. Gemeah's personal accounts of the Arab Spring and watching Operation Iraqi Freedom on television, how people native to the region interpreted US involvement post-9/11
3) I learned about state secularization efforts in Iran and Turkey and how the two regions had similar motivations but vastly different outcomes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Gained basic understanding of the development of the Middle East as a region and major historic forces behind it. Was introduced to a variety of primary sources and learned to engage with them. Improved my skills of source analysis and historical writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of knowledge of the early history of the Middle East (ie. Ottoman Empire), and how this period connects to modern history. I also learned how to critically analyze primary sources, especially films, and how to accurately use these sources in a paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I developed more skills in finding and understanding both sides of a perspective, as well as just knowing more about how visual and written primary sources are equally as helpful in understanding history. Additionally, I think I gained more insight into the US' role in the Middle East and how it is often not as it is presented to the American public.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course greatly enhanced my critical thinking and my ability to draw connections between seemingly disparate historical events and trends. My understanding of the US's relationship with the Middle East grew tremendously and this course expanded my capacity for empathy in thinking about certain political movements that I previously disagreed with.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I always thought of the middle east as very separate from the western world, and this course taught me that that is completely false. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I very much liked the homework design and thought it accompanied the class well, including the Cafe Ivrit conversation hours that were held to encourage outside-of-class interaction with Hebrew. One of the other major components of the course was the portfolio, which was helpful but also a bit ambiguous in its purpose. As a place to summarize out-of-class Hebrew experiences (this was my interpretation), I found this helpful, but then I don't understand the point of spending valuable time on formatting rather than the content. I was also seeing different interpretations throughout the class. If this is truly meant to be a "choose your own adventure" style of project, I would recommend grading it as such—if people don't think formatting is going to be intellectually stimulating, look to the components they list. If there was a more material realization to the project, I would recommend providing some examples so people can focus their effort on the intellectually-stimulating task at hand.

response_text: This course gave me so much more context to understand the situation in Israel-Palestine and helped me to develop the skills to approach understanding longstanding conflict. Learning to think about how to make compromises between groups with so much animosity was incredibly interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to approach the Israeli-Palestinian conflict with numerous perspectives. I learned how to write critically and analyze readings. I also learned the deep history of the conflict which I didn't know existed.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I left the class with my analytical writing skills much better than they were previously.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how international law is created and applied, and the way that laws are subject to interpretation and exploitation based on the minutae of their wording.  We learned about how natural resource management requires inter-state collaboration that can be challenging in conflict-prone areas, and how such collaboration can be leveraged to further political gain.  We learned about how to use first-hand and narrative sources to trace the development of political ideologies and movements, and how to consider the experiences of individuals in conflict.  We learned, most of all, that the conflict between Israel and Palestine is a deeply complicated one with extensive historical background underlying the actions and motivations of both sides.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This was an incredible course.  The instructors handled the sensitivity of the topic deftly and compassionately, and the grace with which they were able to instruct this course in such a difficult political environment speaks volumes to the thoughtfulness and skill that went into crafting the class.  They worked to build a space in which discussion was safe and encouraged, which allowed us to have frank conversations and ask questions without fear. I really appreciated the emphasis on not bringing in current events as we were learning, because it encouraged us to build the necessary background knowledge before drawing judgments.  The way that the class began-- starting twice-- set a powerful precedent for the way we examined this history and taught us the importance of taking an analytical approach to learning history.  I really enjoyed the readings that we completed before class, which tiled in the history and significance of various historical periods while allowing us to connect to them personally.  I also loved the format of the analytical responses, which encouraged continuous engagement with source material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should absolutely sign up for this course. You won't just learn about what happened, you will be asked to engage directly with thehuman dimensions of this conflict and confront the difficult realities of the past and current situation.  This class is a must take.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about Islamic religion and culture I never knew before, such as how Muslims greatly differed in their style of interpretation of scripture and how their scripture was revealed; I learned about how there is no such thing as a single scripture or a shared belief because religion changes constantly and is constantly interpreted; I learned that each Abrahamic faith has a specific tradition of interpretation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. Learning about the three different major monotheistic religions is learning three specific things in and of themselves. Learning about religion in a historical context is one of the most interesting things to learn and I've learned to shift my thinking from a theological prespective to a historical critical one. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the evolution of the three main Abrahamic texts. I learned how scripture is interpreted, who interprets it, and how that has shaped the communities of different religions. I learned how to be a historic critic of religious texts and why that role is ESSENTIAL to understanding society and religion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how scriptures of Islam, Christianity, and Judaism are compiled and interpreted. I also learned about the basic structure of each religious text.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Reading scripture as "a book" rather than a religious text
Learned different methods of interpretation
learned the history that led to the evolution of these different interpretations

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to look at scriptures from a historical and critical perspective rather than a religious one
I learned about the canonization of each scripture and the complexities behind each
I learned of how each of the religions cope with issues and how they try to modernize

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to distinguish between religion and scripture from a scholarly perspective. We learned different words in Greek, Hebrew, and Arabic. We also learned about different key figures in each religious tradition.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed the reading to help facilitate learning in lectures and I also appreciated that we had a guided reflection to fill out about the readings. It held me accountable to do my readings and engage with them. I also just enjoyed the overall structure of the class and how it would shift from each religion and how there would aslo be days where our professors would teach on a common topic. Additional to the structure I enjoyed that there were only two major assignments to do throughout the whole semester.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The readings were "good" for the most part. It's definitely the right idea, but sometimes the instructions were vague and the links were hard to find. I would certainly keep these graded readings, and expand on the feedback. The lectures were always excellent and the professors always came OVERLY prepared. It was impressive and refreshing to be taught by professors who had too many slides and could talk for hours on their subject. Don't change a thing about the lectures.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text: This has got to be the most interesting class I've ever taken. It was very inteluctally stimulating and I've learned so much. It has helped develop the way that I think about religion in a theological context and also has just given me a different viewpoint on history in general because religion has such a pivitol role in history.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how the Bible was created using the documentary hypothesis. We examined how the Bible was used in America in the slavery, abortion, and death penalty debates. I was able to create my own website discussing the Bible on a topic of my choosing guided by Dr. Brettler.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Way of thinking: historical critical perspective of the Bible
Understanding of the flaws of the Bible, different translations, the way different people/religions will emphasize completely different parts of the same passage and gain a completely different meaning. How the Bible impacts American politics and American history. Defining misuse of the Bible. How to construct a website using wordpress, how to find images for a virtual exhibit, how to make a virtual exhibit, how to make a website accessible for others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 8 different lecturers who were each so passionately involved with their respective traditions was genuinely so interesting and engaging every lecture. This method of changing topics every class made it easy to understand distinctions between units and ideas, and kept me invested in the course. I also really enjoyed having a journal and doing journal entries, as they were very personal and helped me reflect on my views in a very informal way. The dialogue group/dialogue performance was also great, as I got to build relationships with my classmates and produce something fun. The final reflective project and retreat were also great. Overall, having such dynamic meetings and assignments made the course really enjoyable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

Transforming my worldview & my view of my undergraduate experience—what to prioritize, how to proceed with intentionality. —> Realizing the importance of slowing down & being present.The faculty are incredible. Guest speaker conversations (with dinner), especially the one focused on the Israel-Hamas War, really helped me ground reflection into the way I approached politics—it made me realize that religion can't really exist independently of politics, which changed the way I thought about political engagement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We became well-versed in modern European short fiction and the genre's many renowned authors, such as Kafka, Svevo, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Pirandello, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. We examined these works through the lens of five primary themes—animals, family and home, love, guilt, and the Holocaust—and determined how the stories can be categorized under one or more of these themes. We learned the distinction between modernism, post-modernism, existentialism, absurdism, communism, syndicalism, anarchism, and other ideologies in a literary context. We had the privilege of visiting the Rare Books library and picking works to analyze closely and the Nasher to look at the works of Chagall, Dali, and other relevant artists, as well as to do a compare/contrast essay on a short story and its film adaptation. These experiences allowed us to appreciate the important differences between different media: short vs. long-form fiction, final versions vs. galley proofs, film, and art. I also learned how to write a concise but effective paper, since our longest paper had a limit of three pages. Lastly, I learned how to appropriately analyze a short story by taking into consideration the plot, characters, author, and political/social implications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about how to analyze literary works in relation to their  historical context. I learned about surrealism in literature and I also learned about the impact of stylistic features and literary devices (as similitudes or imagery) on the reader.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze writing styles, word choice, and how to access the rarebook library.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think my analytical writing improved. I gained a better understanding and general knowledge of European literature.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Got better at analytical writing, was exposed to writers of Europe's past, and got better at interpretive reading.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained substantial knowledge of authors, works, and movements that are significant to European literature.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I love the way the course was structured, both the overarching structure of different themes for different groups of stories and the day-to-day structure of reading 1-5 short stories for class, coming to class to discuss in-depth, and then writing a short paper about a handful of these stories later on. I loved the unique opportunities the class had to offer, namely the Rare Books and Nasher visits and Francesca Magario guest lecture (I loved that lecture!). I loved the variety of papers: the close reading of a Kafka short short story, Rare Books object paper, animal research paper, and film and passage comparison essay. This is also the only humanities class in which I've had an exam, but I think it made sense to include it as an assessment because it forced me to stay on top of the readings (and come to class) and not just skim them. It meant I thoroughly read each story to learn the author's style and the story's influence. Professor Z is very insightful, prepared for class, engaging, and accommodating with deadlines, and she really shines when her students reciprocate an interest in the content. I was in a class with her last semester where the students were in general less engaged, which I think limited her teaching. This time around, most of the class came having done the readings with interesting takeaways/interpretations and ready to discuss, and this meant she could offer more as a professor as well. The professor and the students, in addition to the stories we read, made this class truly one of my favorites that I have taken at Duke.

response_text: The class continuously operated in a space between discussion and lecture that I don't think was best. First off, it couldn't really operate as a discussion with there being 25 people in the class. I think breaking up classes, or parts of each class, into either lecture or discussion would be more engaging and let the material stick more. I think students would get more out of it that way.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take this course if you can! It was one of my favorite classes that I have taken at Duke. The readings are both thought-provoking and entertaining, as are the in-class discussions we had about them. By the end of the course, you'll be able to say that you're well-versed in modern European short fiction authors like Kafka, Joyce, Woolf, Dostoevsky, Mann, Sartre, Camus, etc. You get to do some cool out-of-class excursions too, like to the Rare Books library and the Nasher. The professor is very knowledgeable, effectively facilitates class discussions, and is very accommodating with deadlines. Plus the papers are very short (max 3 pages). There is one exam where you have to match 12 or so quotes to their author/work and write about the immediate context and significance of the quote, but it is very doable if you do all the readings and come to class consistently. I genuinely have no criticisms of this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned how the World Wars shaped the development of states in the Middle East
2) I learned, through Dr. Gemeah's personal accounts of the Arab Spring and watching Operation Iraqi Freedom on television, how people native to the region interpreted US involvement post-9/11
3) I learned about state secularization efforts in Iran and Turkey and how the two regions had similar motivations but vastly different outcomes

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Gained basic understanding of the development of the Middle East as a region and major historic forces behind it. Was introduced to a variety of primary sources and learned to engage with them. Improved my skills of source analysis and historical writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of knowledge of the early history of the Middle East (ie. Ottoman Empire), and how this period connects to modern history. I also learned how to critically analyze primary sources, especially films, and how to accurately use these sources in a paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think I developed more skills in finding and understanding both sides of a perspective, as well as just knowing more about how visual and written primary sources are equally as helpful in understanding history. Additionally, I think I gained more insight into the US' role in the Middle East and how it is often not as it is presented to the American public.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I have taken a lot of history courses that focus on ancient history, so taking one that extended to the modern day gave me a really complete picture of how exactly the modern situations have been created.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Baker is extremely kind and cared a lot about each student and helping them do well. Her class was extremely organized and well-structured which helped me succeed. There were portfolios we created throughout the semester that helped me understand my progress as we went through the course, and the mini quizzes helped me stay on track in terms of grammar rules. It was also awesome having the freedom of picking any topic to present on for my in class presentation - I had never presented on a topic in Hebrew before so it was a great experience for me. It was also great to have required conversation hours because it helped me improve my speaking skills!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I think that was a great way to make sure everyone was getting something out of the course, no matter how much they came in knowing.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I wish the class was less focused on the textbook. I wish we incorporated even more applications of Israeli culture, or even just general discussions about life in Hebrew.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the quizzes kept the class stimulated, it made sure that we were on top of our work and keeping up with the binyanim.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because it required significant engagement with the course material.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think my biggest wish was that had done more that applied to current times and modern Hebrew versus all the grammar and structure of sentences, for example. I know that grammar is obviously an important part of the language, but I think it is also important to learn about things beyond the rules. For example, it would have been cool to have a class on Israeli slang, and see what words and phrases are actually very common in Israel. I also wish we had done a bit more with pop culture. We had a poet come in to speak to us and we read his work, and I really enjoyed that, so I think doing more of that or watching an episode of an Israeli TV show or listening to Israeli songs and talking about them could be very beneficial. Basically, I just think we should have done more that exposed us to real Israeli culture (that would also help with our understanding of the language) than we did.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are looking to do Hebrew for your language requirement I highly recommend it!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I took Hebrew for all of my growing up life, and was really excited to improve my speaking skills by taking it at Duke. Whatever I was expecting, though, was not what I was met with. Prof. Baker is very kind, enthusiastic, and fair in her assignments and her grading; that said, we spent the entire semester reviewing grammar forms that I learned in middle school and early high school.While this was a nice review, I can confidently say that I did not learn speak and write any more fluently, did not pick up any slang or the ability to watch fast-paced Hebrew movies, and did not read real Hebrew literature. We worked out of a workbook the entire semester, only read news articles on a platform with small articles meant for Hebrew beginners, and even when we expressed the desire to learn from more applicable sources were not met with engaging, challenging material. Classes were essentially a lecture, with hardly any Hebrew spoken by us. This would have been a good intermediate class, but was definitely not meant to be a 300-level language course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is definitely a lot of work. Most of the homework is helpful but sometimes can feel like busy work, and a lot of in class time it feels like we spend just going over the same things. However, I have definitely learned a lot in this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class will help you tremendously improve your speaking, writing, and grammar skills, in addition to getting exposed to a wide array of Israeli culture.

response_text: This is a very rewarding class and is helpful for mastering hebrew. You learn grammar styles and important irregulars that are helpful. I would highly recommend this class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the post-war discussion and knowledge surrounding the Holocaust and WWII in Germany. It was something that I had never learned about; I always learned about the Holocaust, but never the intellectual aftermath. I also learned some film methods and techniques, since this class was an ALP and we watched a decent amount of movies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I developed a range of knowledge, skills, and insights that have significantly enriched my understanding of the subject matter. One specific thing I learned was the importance of critical thinking and analysis. Through various assignments and class discussions, I honed my ability to evaluate arguments, assess evidence, and identify logical fallacies, enabling me to approach complex issues with a more discerning eye. Additionally, I gained a deeper appreciation for the power of effective communication. Whether it was through written assignments and class discussions, I learned how to articulate my ideas clearly and persuasively, tailoring my message to different audiences and contexts. Lastly, this course exposed me to diverse perspectives and challenged my preconceived notions. By engaging with classmates from various backgrounds and exploring different viewpoints, I developed a greater sense of empathy and cultural awareness, fostering a more inclusive and open-minded way of thinking. Overall, these three specific learnings—critical thinking, effective communication, and embracing diversity—have not only enhanced my academic abilities but also equipped me with invaluable skills for navigating the complexities of the world beyond the classroom.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I continued the development of my language proficiency. Throughout the semester, I received many opportunities to practice my German through different activities targeting writing, reading, listening, and speaking. By the end of the course, I felt particularly proud of my improved reading skills. I found the texts to be quite challenging, but ultimately led to immense improvements in my German reading comprehension. I also developed a greater understanding of Jewish-German history and culture in the Modernist time period. I had already consumed some of the media (film and literature mainly) that we discussed in this course, but through our in-depth class discussions, I learned to see these and many new materials through alternative perspectives. It was particularly exciting to discuss the context of different works and ponder the potential implications these contexts could have on the overall meaning of literature, film, and art. Finally, this course helped me develop an understanding of and an appreciation for the interconnectedness of people and ideas. Throughout the course, we saw the connections and overlap between the authors, artists, filmmakers, and philosophers located in Berlin, Prague, and Vienna. It truly made me appreciate and ponder the ways in which information is spread. And, how inspiration is spread as well.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't do the readings. They suck and don't help you understand the course at all. Skim whatever you need to finish the reading assignments. Go to every lecture, even if you don't pay attention. On the papers, talk with the professors often. They will give you good advice and direction.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is very different than the traditional class you will take at Duke. Professors really prioritize learning rather than testtaking.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It is definitely interesting and you'll learn a lot just prepare to read.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had to rethink the relationship between history, cannon, and popular culture. Through this, we learned how many dominant religious traditions were distorted from the literal biblical text. We learned to read texts carefully and compare how translations get... lost in translation. lol

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned so much!! I can't pinpoint three exact things but I got a better understanding of the role in pop culture in both historical times and now, as well as learned a lot about biblical passages.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- how to critically think about the Bible and what its use in pop culture means about society and how we find meaning in religion today 
- learned how the Hebrew translation provides more depth to my understanding of Bible stories 
- how to analyze pop culture images

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was fantastic in helping me to go beyond my previous conceptions about the bible. Specifically, I learned what it means to interpret the bible, I learned where biblical figures are present in popular culture, and I learned how much of an influence the bible has had on the media we consume.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. how to read the Bible in an academic perspective
2. How the Bible relates to popular culture
3. Historical meaning through different Biblical texts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Critically analyze a piece of media
Knowledge about figures in the Bible in popular culture

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze biblical text by placing it into context. I learned about how prevalent religion is in daily life through film and music, and I learned how to connect the bible and popular culture to create a cohesive argument.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: they are both experts in their field and are impressive fountains of knowledge. They are great at lecturing and breaking down concepts slowly to build up to their points and give us a lot of grace with lack of our historical knowledge. they fill us in on what we miss well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the readings and short assignments!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- super engaged and interesting 
- the two different perspectives and areas of expertise was intensely beneficial 
- the structure of the class was very helpful to approach analyzes pop culture: 1st half of class textual analysis and 2nd half pop culture

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Both Dr. Brettler and Dr. Coates helped tremendously with making the course accessible to all, especially if people did not come in with significant biblical background. We were given readings that were easily digestible, and each one had a clear purpose that would be discussed in the following class. I would not change anything in particular about the class - I really enjoyed it.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The incorporation of using class discussion on things that were brought up by the professor was helpful in furthering my understanding of the topic of conversation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the Sakai assignments, which made me summarize what I had learned every week and made me more prepared for discussions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved how tight-knit the group felt in class. I think keeping the class size small is a good idea, because as the semester progressed we all got more comfortable with each other. I would keep the chronological order of the class, it made the flow logical.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: it was stimulating to have two very different types of reading every week, one more "fun" one and one more "academic" one, it was a nice dichotomy. also, it's stimulating to talk celebs in class always

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Every reading felt incredibly relevant. I really enjoyed the different perspectives that were incorporated in the readings, especially the ones on popular culture.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the facilitation of discussion by the professors was helpful

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very intellectually stimulating because the dynamic between the two professors, who were very different in subject knowledge but it integrated very well

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The structure of this class (biblical text portion first and then pop element) with a break in between was really helpful.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: definitely take it, you'll to gain more basic knowledge of the bible that you didn't know you needed to know and have fun while doing it >@<

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a great course--pairing Dr. Coates and Dr. Brettler together makes for really interesting discussions and their strengths complement each other within the biblical stories. The readings are relevant and provide good insight before each class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: -take this class!!!!!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You will not be disappointed if you take this class!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I think it is helpful but come into the class with an open mind and no assumptions of the Bible. This way you can attack the class and have an open opinion on all topics

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is most rewarding if you already have a lot of knowledge in popular culture.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will make you think and it is definitely important to come to class prepared to discuss material in the readings. Also, it is important to be prepared to receive pushback on an point you make in class. Overall, the course is so fun and will make you laugh.
